Sous Vide 101: Duck Breast Recipe

J. Kenji Lpez-Alt
  • Profile
  • Twitter
  • Facebook
  • Contact
30 Printer-Friendly Version

This recipe requires the use of a sous-vide cooker or the beer cooler hack.

As a meat that is best served medium rare, duck breast makes an ideal candidate to cook sous-vide. By cooking it at 130F for two hours, much of the fat under the skin begins to soften and render out while the proteins in it begin to set, making it easier to crisp without shrinking on the stovetop just before serving.

The thickness of the skin means that you can also crisp it more gently post sous-viding, unlike a steak which requires blazing high heat to cut back on cooking time and prevent the interior from overcooking. The skin acts as an insulator, preventing the meat inside from taking on any more color. The result is supremely tender, evenly cooked meat with super crisp skin.

For best results, I like to season the breasts and let them sit uncovered in the fridge at least overnight to allow some moisture to evaporate and concentrate its duckiness. Isn't that just ducky?

Fruity sauces and some steamed greens round out the dish. Try the lingonberry jam from IKEA. It's splendid.

Read more: The New $199 Sansaire Sous Vide Circulator is the Solution We've Been Waiting For

  • Yield:Serves 4
  • Active time: 15 minutes
  • Total time:1 hour or up to 4 hours and 15 minutes
  • Rated: 5

Ingredients

  • 4 boneless duck breasts (about 5 to 6 ounces each; 150-175g)
  • Kosher salt and freshly cracked black pepper

Directions

  1. 1.

    Season duck generously with salt and pepper. For best results, place on a plate and refrigerate uncovered overnight before proceeding.

  2. 2.

    Seal duck in vacuum bags. Place in 130F (54C) water bath for at least 45 minutes and up to 4 hours. Remove from bags and dry thoroughly with paper towels.

  3. 3.

    Place breasts skin side-down in heavy-bottomed 12-inch non-stick or cast iron skillet and set over high heat until sizzling, about 2 minutes. Reduce heat to medium and cook, moving and pressing breasts to ensure good contact between skin and pan until golden brown and crisp, about 5 minutes. Flip and cook second side until barely colored, about 30 seconds. Transfer to paper towel-lined plate and allow to rest for 5 minutes.

  4. 4.

    Slice breasts crosswise into 1/2-inch strips and serve.

Special Equipment
sous vide circulator

J. Kenji Lpez-Alt Chief Culinary Advisor
  • Profile
  • Twitter

  • Contact

J. Kenji Lpez-Alt is the Chief Culinary Advisor of Serious Eats, and author of the James Beard Award-nominated column The Food Lab, where he unravels the science of home cooking. A restaurant-trained chef and former Editor at Cook's Illustrated magazine, his first book, The Food Lab: Better Home Cooking Through Science is a New York Times Best-Seller, the recipient of a James Beard Award, and was named Cookbook of the Year in 2015 by the International Association of Culinary Professionals.

He's currently raising a daughter by day, writing his second book by night (Now with 10% more science!), and is working on Wursthall, a beer hall in downtown San Mateo which will be open by the end of 2017.

Order your copy of The Food Lab: Better Home Cooking Through Science today!
